textClass.keywords: Nb-Mo-Ta-W high-entropy alloys Solid solution strengthening Configurational entropy Design of chemical contents

div.p: In the study of high-entropy alloys (HEAs), due to the enormous adjustment space of the content (5-35 at.%) of each principal element, the yield strength at room temperature (RT) of the alloys are basically difficult to estimate. Five kinds of Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs with the same component elements but in different contents were fabricated by vacuum arc melting (VAM). The crystal structures of five kinds of alloys are all single-phase solid solutions of BCC structure. The grain sizes of each alloy are about ~150 Î¼m and the substructures within the grain are typical dendritic. The calculated yield strength through solid solution strengthening (SSS) model by Senkov is in certain agreement with the experimental yield strength of five alloys. In our study, the concept of configurational entropy is brought in to optimize the model. In comparison with the calculated yield strength of original model, the variation trend curve of the optimized model was in better agreement with that in experiment. Moreover, the optimized SSS model has a certain universality to predict the mechanical properties in other refractory HEAs system with a single BCC structure composed of W, Nb, Mo, Ta, Zr, Hf, Ti, V element. This conclusion provides a theoretical basis for the design of chemical contents of BCC structural refractory HEAs systems.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In recent years, the appearance of high entropy alloys (HEAs) with multiple principal elements has broken through the traditional alloy design concept and its outstanding properties [1][2][3][4] have attracted extensive attention. In terms of the definition of HEAs, in 2004, Yeh et al. [5] defined HEAs as alloys with five or more principal elements and each principal element should have a concentration between 5 and 35 at.%.

Currently, HEAs can be divided into two types according to their chemical composition: (1) HEAs with equalatomic ratio, such as NbMoTaWV [2], CoCrFeMnNi [6] and AlCoCrFeNi [7]. (2) HEAs with non-equalatomic ratio, such as CoCrFeMnNiV x (x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1) [8], Al x CoCrFeNi (x = 0-2.0) [9]. Non-equiatomic ratio HEA generally regulates the mechanical properties by changing the mole proportion of a certain principal element in the alloy while the other principal elements occupying the rest of contents in equal mole ratios. However, the adjustment space of the composition content of each principle element is enormous (5-35 at.%). When the content of each principle element in HEAs varies greatly, the mechanical properties of the alloys are basically difficult to estimate. Therefore, a scientific theory is needed to predict the mechanical properties of HEAs with the same component elements but in different contents.
There are many approaches of strengthening mechanisms for predicting the room temperature (RT) mechanical properties of HEAs [10]:

The lattice distortion effect is considered as an essential factor that affects the mechanical properties. The severe lattice distortion comes from different kinds of elements with different atom sizes. In several previous studies, Nguyen et al. [11] consider the strength of Ti-Zr-Nb-Ta alloy system positively correlates with the atomic radius difference. The same conclusion can also be obtained in Nb-Mo-Cr-Ti-Al HEAs system [12]. As shear modulus do not change significantly with compositions, this approach mainly considers the atomic size difference of the composed elements.

Another approach to model solid solution strengthening (SSS) in HEAs was proposed by Senkov et al. [13] and applied to HfNbTaTiZr HEA. In this model, the rule of mixture mechanical property, atomic size difference and shear modulus difference are associated comprehensively. The model mainly relies on the traditional SSS of binary solid solution (SS) systems proposed by Labush [14]. In the absence of considering thermally-activated processes, the calculated result is in good agreement with the experimental result. After that, Yao et al. [15] used the model and calculated RT yield strength and Vikers hardness for 14 equiatomic refractory HEAs. The calculated results are in satisfactory agreement with the experimental results. Although both the selection of certain parameters, constants and some details of the mathematical calculation are slightly different, the theoretically calculated yield strength of a series of refractory HEAs and medium-entropy alloys (MEAs) for TaNbHfZrTi [16], (TiZrNbTa)-Mo [17], NbTaTiV [18], NbMoTa [19] is in good agreement with the experimental yield strength through this model.

Coury et al. [20] modeled the yield strength of single-phase BCC refractory HEAs through the summation of athermal solid-solution strengthening component and thermally-activated yield stress component. The thermally-activated yield stress contributes an essential role in the high yield strengths of HEAs at RT.
There are other models that consider calculating the yield stress at any given temperature through the critical resolved shear stress (CRSS).

The main research about the CRSS are dislocations type. Maresca and Curtin [21] proposed a general theory of strengthening of screw dislocations in a broad class of BCC random HEAs. Later, they [22] found the strengthening of Mo-Nb-Ta-V-W refractory HEAs systems may be controlled by edge dislocations over a wide temperature range. Rao et al. [23] modeled the dislocation behavior in a randomly-distributed model-BCC Co 16.67 Fe 36.67 Ni 16.67 Ti 30 alloy. The CRSS in true random alloy required to move the equilibrium a/2â©111âª screw dislocation is much larger than in a "mean-field" version of the same alloy composition. In addition, Rao et al. [24] studies the large scale, atomistic simulations of the core structure and mobility of Â½[111] screw, edge and mixed dislocations in ternary NbTiZr, Nb 1.5 TiZr 0.5 and Nb 0.5 TiZr 1.5 multicomponent alloys. In their work, small amounts of interstitials can have a significant impact on the yield strength and of refractory HEAs.

The Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs system was selected to predict the conventional mechanical properties (Vickers microhardness and yield strength) at RT due to its unique characteristics. In 2010, Senkov et al. [2,25] obtain the equiatomic ratio NbMoTaW and VNbMoTaW refractory HEAs with a simple single-phase BCC structure for the first time through vacuum arc melting (VAM) process. The melting point of NbMoTaW alloy is higher than 2500 Â°C, and the yield strength is 405 MPa at 1600 Â°C. In 2015, Zou et al. [1] found that the yield strength of NbMoTaW HEA at the nanometer size exceeded 10 GPa, and the compressive strain could reach more than 30%. The compressive yield strength was the highest among all the reported micro/nano metal materials. In 2020, Moorehead et al. [26] tested 31 kinds of Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs with different chemical compositions and found that all HEAs showed the single-phase BCC structure. Compared to the multi-phase refractory HEAs, the single phase HEAs remains high strength with increasing temperature above 1000 Â°C [27].

In this study, five kinds of Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs with the same component elements but in different contents were designed and then formed by the VAM process. The microstructure and mechanical properties at RT were characterized and tested. In the absence of considering thermally-activated processes, we substitute the concept of configurational entropy into the SSS model by Senkov. In comparison with the calculated yield strength at RT of the original model, the variation trend curve of the optimized yield strength was in better agreement with that in experiment, which provided a theoretical basis for the design of chemical contents of BCC structural refractory HEAs systems.

div.head: Chemical contents design
div.p: Five kinds of Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs with the same component elements but in different contents were fabricated by VAM process. The characteristics of Nb, Mo, Ta, and W elements are shown in Table 1. Alloy 1 has the largest degree of lattice distortion; Alloy 2 has the lowest degree of lattice distortion; Alloy 3 has the largest rule of mixture (ROM) microhardness, Alloy 4 has the lowest ROM microhardness. Alloy 5, as the control group, is the equiatomic ratio NbMoTaW HEA. The chemical contents of the five kinds of HEAs are shown in Table 2.

div.head: Materials preparation
div.p: Elemental powders of Nb (99.78 wt%), Ta (99.90 wt%) W (99.50 wt %) powders were provided by Beijing AMC Powder Metallurgy Technology Co., Ltd. and Mo (99.84 wt%) were provided by H.C. Starck Inc.

The microstructure morphology of four powders is shown in Fig. 1. Five kinds of a mixture of powders were homogenized via a three-dimensional motion mixer series for 4 h at the speed of 10 rpm of the principal axis.

Five kinds of a mixture of powders were pressed into a Ï36 Ã 15 cylindrical shape by a YT32-200 four-column hydraulic press respectively, used for raw material of the VAM process. A VRFJ-A vacuum arc melting equipment was used to arc-melt the cylinder to fabricate the HEA ingots. Before the VAM process, the arc chamber was evacuated to 6.5 Ã 10 -3 Torr and the residual gases in the chamber were consumed by high purity Ti. The mixtures were arc-melted in a water-cooled copper hearth for approximately 30 s. Each ingot was remelted five timesand was inverted in each melt to achieve a uniform distribution of elements.

div.head: Microstructural and mechanical characterization
div.p: Structural characterization of the HEAs was conducted on the crosssection by X'Pert PRO PW 3040160 X-ray diffraction equipment. A Cu KÎ± radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA was used to produce an X-ray with a wavelength of 1.5405980 Scan range from 20Â° to 130Â° with a 0.0167Â° step size. The microstructures and microscopic segregations of alloys

div.head: Table 4
div.p: The specific values of yield strength, compressive strength and compressive strain in 5 alloys. were analyzed by SU3500 SEM with a backscatter electron (BSE) and an energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) detector. The oxygen and nitrogen contents of HEAs were measured by a LECO TC500 equipment. The Vickers microhardness of the HEAs was measured by an HXD-2000TMSC/LCD tester. All of the alloys were tested on polished longitudinal-section surfaces and the measured locations were within the grain to eliminate the effect of grain boundaries on the microhardness of the alloys. Each alloy was measured in 10 randomly selected locations and the test parameter was applied for the 30 s under a 500 g load. In compression mechanical performance testing, 3 samples of each alloy with 6 mm in height and 4 mm in diameter were cut near the center of the ingot to make the grain number in all samples as consistent as possible. The test was conducted by a Sans CMT4304 multifunction static experiment machine at a strain rate of 0.001 s -1 at 25 Â°C.

div.head: Phase, microstructure and texture analysis
div.p: Table 3 shows the contents of five kinds Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs in the longitudinal section of ingot respectively, determined by EDS detector. It can be found that the composition of the elements in each alloy is close to the ratio of the design. At previous study [20,24], small amounts of interstitial elements like oxygen and nitrogen can have a significant impact on the yield strength in a wide temperature range. In this study, the oxygen and nitrogen content of the samples after compression test were shown in Table 3. The values of interstitial elements are relatively small compared to the yield strength tested in our work [20]. Therefore, the effect of interstitials were not considered in our work.

Fig. 2 exhibits the XRD patterns of 5 kinds Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs. Only purely BCC peaks without additional signals can be detected in each pattern and it can be concluded that all five alloys have a single phase of disordered BCC. The values of precipitate or dispersion strengthening yield strength is supposed to be zero in single phase alloys.
Fig. 3 shows the BSE and EDS images of 5 kinds of Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs. Fig. 3

div.head: Table 5
div.p: The relative atomic size difference, Î´ aij (underlined numbers), and Î´ Gij modulus difference, (bold numbers), between elements pairs in Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs system. which is consistent with the NbMoTaW HEAs fabricated by the VAM process [25]. Fig. 3 (c), (f), (i), (l) and (o) show the distribution of Nb, Mo, Ta, W elements in each alloy. All elements are uniformly distributed and there is no obvious element enrichment area.

div.head: Comprehensive mechanical property
div.p: The comprehensive mechanical properties of the five alloys are shown in Fig. 4.Fig. 4-(a) shows the Vickers microhardness. To eliminate the effect of grain boundary on the Vickers microhardness, measured locations were within the grain, shown in Fig. 4-(b). Fig. 4-(c) shows the compressive stress-strain curves of five alloys at room temperature and Fig. 4-(d) shows the yield strength (YS), compressive strength (CS), and compressive strain of each alloy. It can be found that the yield strength at RT has a certain positive correlation with the compressive strain in 5 alloys. Also, the Vikers microhardness and yield strength of the alloys change in a consistent trend. (Table 4 shows the specific values of yield strength, compressive strength and compressive strain in each test sample.)

div.head: Lattice distortion effect model
div.p: As one of the four 'core effects' of HEAs, the lattice distortion effect is considered as an essential factor that affects the mechanical properties. In pure metals, the lattice is standard, shown in Fig. 5-(a). In one principal element alloys, the lattice site is mainly occupied by the principal element, and there is a certain degree of lattice distortion, shown in Fig. 5-(b). However, for HEAs, in the case of ignoring the chemical short-range ordering, each element has the same probability to occupy each lattice site, causing severe lattice distortion, shown in Fig. 5-(c). This effect can be described directly related to differences in atomic size (Î´ r ), by the following equation [31,32]:
div.formula: = = = = c r r r c r 100 (1 / ) ; r i n i i i n i i 1 2 1 (1)
div.p: where c i, i are the atomic fractions and atom radii of the i-th elements respectively. Through this equation, it can be recognized the atomic radius difference of the HEA is positively correlated with the degree of lattice distortion.

The relation between the experimental yield strength (YS) at RT, Vikers microhardness (Hv) and lattice distortion degree is shown in Fig. 6. According to the experimental mechanical properties of five kinds of Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs in section 3.2, it can be concluded that there is no obvious mathematical rule for the lattice distortion degree on the mechanical properties of five alloys due to the significant change of the ROM shear modulus of alloys.

div.head: Solid solution strengthening model by Senkov
div.p: SSS can be regarded from the elastic interaction between the local stress field of a solute atom and those of dislocation. There are mainly two kinds of approach: Fleisher's approach [33] and Labush's approach [14]. Currently, Labush's approach is widely used to predict yield strength in HEAs [13,17].
The value for SSS ÎÏ i can be obtained:
where A is a fitting material-dependent dimensionless constant, c i is the i solute concentration, and Î´ i is the mismatch parameter determined by:
div.formula: = + = = dG dc G da dc a 1 | |/2 ; 1 ; 1 Gi Gi Gi Gi i ai i (4)
div.p: here Î´ Gi ' represents the elastic misfit while ai represents the atomic size misfit. Î² is a parameter, which value depends on the type of mobile dislocation. For screw-type dislocations, Î² is 2-4 while Î² â¥ 16 for edgetype dislocations [33].

As for constant A and parameter Î², In the previous study by Wang and Xu [17], when A is assumed to be 0.0222, the predicted yield strength in 34 available single-phase refractory HEAs is in satisfactory agreement with the experimental yield strength. For a type of mobile dislocation, Maresca and Curtin [22] found the strengthening of Nb-Mo-Ta-W refractory HEAs systems may be controlled by edge dislocations over a wide temperature range. The similar conclusions are also proposed by Wang and Xu [17], Toda-caraballo and Rivera-DÃ­az-Del-Castillo [34]. There the Î² is assumed to be 16.

In HEAs BCC solid solutions. The atomic size and modulus mismatches between atoms cause the local lattice distortion. The Î´ ai and Î´ Gi in the vicinity of an element i can be estimated as an average of the atomic size difference and atomic modulus difference:
div.formula: = c 8 ai j aij (5) = c 9 8 Gi j Gij (6)
div.p: where c j is atom fraction of j element in the alloy. Î´ aij = 2(r i -r j )/ (r i + r j ) is the atomic size difference of elements i and j, while
div.formula: Î´ Gij = 2(G i -G j )/(G i + G j )
div.p: is the shear modulus difference between elements i and j. The atomic radius, shear modulus and yield strength of each element are listed in Table 1. The calculated parameters of Î´ aij , Î´ Gij , are presented in Table 5. Substitute all the calculated parameters of each element into the Eq. ( 2). Then the ÎÏ of alloys can be expressed in the following:
Finally, the calculated yield strength of the HEAs is equal to the sum of the rule of mixture yield strength (Ï s mix ) and ÎÏ:

According to the above equation, the calculated yield strength of the 5 kinds of alloys is shown in Table 6. Fig. 7 shows the relationship between calculated yield strength and experimental yield strength of the alloys. It can be concluded that the calculated yield strength of the HEAs has a well correlation with the experimental yield strength. However, the experimental yield strength of alloy 3, which theoretically should have the highest calculated yield strength, is less than that of alloy 5 with equalatomic ratio, which will be discussed in section 4.3.

div.head: Optimization of solid solution strengthening model
div.p: In the previous studies on refractory HEAs with the same component elements but in different contents [11,16,17,35,36], we found that the HEAs with equalatomic ratio have the highest yield strength in most conditions [11,17,35,36].

As the name of HEAs implies, high entropy effect is the first essential core effect. Tsai and Yeh [37] stated that higher mixing entropy (mainly configurational) in HEAs lowers the free energy of solid solution phases and enhances the formation of solid solution phases. Also, this effect could increase and make the micro-structure much simpler [38].

The high entropy effect could enhance the mutual solubility between constituent elements. In Gao et al. [38] literature, this effect could increase the strength and ductility of solution phases due to solution hardening. Zhang et al. [39] also proposed that the high entropy of mixing truly extends the solubility limits of solid solution, and the SSS increases with the increase of solute concentration. To sum up, we consider the entropy of HEAs will affect the yield strength in HEAs systems with the same component elements but in different contents.

The study of high entropy effect mainly focused on configurational entropy of ideal solutions [40]. Therefore, we use the magnitude of configurational entropy to represent the entropy of the HEAs systems, shown as follows:
div.formula: = = S R c c ln conf i n i i 1 (9)
div.p: In the SSS model of the HEAs in section 4.2, the high entropy effect on yield strength of HEAs at RT was not taken into consideration. We add a dimensionless constant into Eq. ( 8) to express the influence of configurational entropy on the yield strength of HEAs at RT:
div.formula: = + S S s cal s mix conf conf max n(10)
div.p: where ÎS conf ' is the configurational entropy of the calculated alloy, ÎS conf max is the maximum configurational entropy with the same component elements. n is a constant and its value can be obtained in the following fitting. In Eq. ( 10), the magnitude of configurational entropy on yield strength at RT has been taken into consideration. When the calculated alloy the HEA with equalatomic ratio, the configurational entropy is equal to the maximum configurational entropy and the Eq. ( 10) is consistent with Eq. ( 8). The relation between the yield strength calculated by Eq. ( 10) and experimental Vikers microhardness, yield strength is shown in Fig. 8 and Table 7 different constant n. In Fig. 8, as the magnitude of constant n increases, the variation trend curve of calculated yield strength and experimental yield strength of five alloys comes more and more ideal than that of n = 0, shown in Fig. 8-(a) and (b). When n = 3, the variation trend of the calculated yield strength is in best agreement with that of experimental yield strength, shown in Fig. 8-(c). After that, as the magnitude of constant n continues to increase, the variation trend comes worse, shown in Fig. 8-(d).

This optimized SSS model is not only feasible in the Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs system, but also in other BCC single structural refractory HEAs systems composed of W, Nb, Mo, Ta, Zr, Hf, Ti, V element. The atomic radius, shear modulus and yield strength of Zr, Hf, Ti and elements are shown in Table 8. In previous studies [11,16,35,36], the experimental yield strength of different refractory BCC structural HEAs systems at RT were counted. At next step, the theoretical yield strength of the above BCC structural HEAs systems was statistical calculated by the model in sections 4.2 and 4.3. When n = 3, the variation trend curve of calculated yield strength by our study and experimental yield strength are in better agreement compared to the yield strength calculated with the SSS model by Senkov, shown in Table 9 and Fig. 9.

In our study, in single phase BCC structural refractory HEAs systems, the high entropy effect will affect the mechanical properties of the systems with the same component elements but in different contents due to solution hardening caused by different configurational entropy. The increase of configurational entropy of HEAs may lead to greater strength in same HEAs system. This conclusion provides a theoretical basis for the chemical contents design of refractory BCC structural HEAs systems.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Several conclusions can be drawn as follows: (a) All the five Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs with same component elements but in different contents fabricated by the VAM process have a single-phase solid solution of BCC structure. In five alloys, the yield strength has a certain positive correlation with the compressive strain. On chemical contents design of the Nb-Mo-Ta-W high-entropy alloy system, it is more possible to obtain alloys with better plasticity by giving priority to the prediction of the yield strength.

(b) Higher mixing entropy (mainly configurational) in HEAs lowers the free energy of solid solution phases and enhances the formation of solid solution phases. The high entropy effect could enhance the mutual solubility between constituent elements and increase the strength and ductility of solution phases due to solution hardening. In Nb-Mo-Ta-W system, different magnitude of the configurational entropy may affect the yield strength of alloys at RT. The concept of configurational entropy is brought in to optimize the SSS model by Senkov.

(c) There is no obvious mathematical rule for the lattice distortion degree on the yield strengths of five kinds of the Nb-Mo-Ta-W HEAs. In the SSS model by Senkov, the calculated yield strength is in certain agreement with the experimental yield strength at RT. However, after optimization, the variation trend curve of calculated yield strength and experimental yield strength was in better agreement. Moreover, the optimized SSS model has a certain universality to predict the yield strength at RT in other refractory HEAs system with a single BCC structure composed of W, Nb, Mo, Ta, Zr, Hf, Ti, V element.
